University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. 'A pain in the butt: Understanding the physiology of Campylobacter jejuni inside and outside the host' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/may/a-pain-in-the-butt-understanding-the-physiology-of-campylobacter-jejuni-inside-and-outside-the-host Bennett Lecture Theatre 2 - 26 May 2015, 12:00PM - 01:00PM No publisher User Submitted College:MedBioPsych Magazine:Staff Event:Lecture Magazine:Research 2015-05-26T11:00:00Z UoL Event History of Seismology Meeting https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/geology/news/history-of-seismology-meeting/introduction-1/history-of-seismology-meeting A meeting to be held at College Court, University of Leicester, UK on the 9th and 10th April 2015 Sponsored by the British Geophysical Association, the History of Physics Group of the Institute of Physics, the Royal Astronomical Society, the Geological Society, Ophir Energy plc, and Shell Global Solutions, BV

Full Registration ends on 20th March 2015

Registration can be completed at http://shop.le.ac.uk (search for Seismology)

The full programme, abstracts, speaker biographies and further meeting information can be accessed via\ufffd\ufffdNews and Events \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd History of Seismology Meeting in\ufffd\ufffdthe adjoining Navigation pane.

The UK has a rich history in the science of Seismology, and it is just over 100 years since the death of John Milne, the man who introduced the word \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdseismometer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd to the science. At a time when major facets of the subject are being, perhaps have been superseded - for example onshore controlled source crustal seismology by passive seismic methods - and so are becoming \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhistorical\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, this meeting has been designed to explore the UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds contribution to Seismology. While science does not recognize national boundaries, the seismological work that has been undertaken in the UK since at least the time of Robert Hooke and the founding of the Royal Society is peculiarly amenable to presentation at an Institute of Physics History of Physics Group sponsored meeting.

The meeting has been divided into four sessions; Earthquakes, Instruments and Institutions, Controlled Source Seismology and Crustal Studies, and Passive Seismology. To ensure the content is not just a reflection of science past, the sessions include topics that highlight outstanding current work, and speakers have been asked to consider future trends in their particular field.

Twenty-two speakers will cover such varied topics as Early British Thinking on Earthquakes, Prediction, Quiet Earthquakes, Test-ban Verification, Schools\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Seismology, Seismic Investigations of the Ocean Floor, Seismology and the Oil and Gas Industry, Tomography and the Outer Earth, Anisotropy, Interferometry and Seismic Noise, Helioseismology, and more.

The meeting will take place over two days, posters being displayed throughout. There will be a conference dinner. The accompanying person programme will include a visit to the Richard III exhibition and tomb, if there is demand.

Registration can be completed at\ufffd\ufffdhttp://shop.le.ac.uk
(search for Seismology)

Full Registration ends on 20th March 2015

]]> No publisher pkm histseis 2015-03-11T22:25:00Z Blog Entry When should blood transfusions be given after cardiac surgery? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/march/when-should-blood-transfusions-be-given-after-cardiac-surgery Professor Gavin Murphy involved in study at Bristol Professor Gavin Murphy (pictured), British Heart Foundation (BHF) Professor of Cardiac Surgery, formerly of the University of Bristol\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds School of Clinical Sciences and now\ufffd\ufffdfrom the Department of Cardiovascular Sciences at Leicester\ufffd\ufffdhas been involved in a new study from the University of Bristol that has shown that patients having heart surgery do not benefit if doctors wait until a patient has become substantially anaemic before giving a transfusion.

In the UK, about half of all patients having cardiac surgery are given a red blood cell transfusion after the operation, using up to ten per cent of the nation\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds blood supply. The proportion of patients having a transfusion is high because blood loss and severe anaemia are common after cardiac surgery and transfusion is the preferred treatment. Blood loss causes anaemia which doctors detect by measuring the red cell count or haemoglobin level \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a low level triggers transfusion.

Cardiac surgery patients who receive blood transfusions are believed to have more complications such as infections, heart attacks and strokes, and this has led to speculation that avoidance of transfusion will improve clinical outcomes.

Professor Murphy said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdExisting national and international transfusion guidelines recommend that blood transfusions only be given to patients who develop very low haemoglobin concentrations. We have shown that this strategy may increase the number of deaths in cardiac surgery.

"This was the largest randomised trial ever conducted in the UK in a surgical or cardiac surgery population. It was the largest trial ever conducted that has considered indications for transfusion in cardiac surgery, and recruited over twice the number of patients recruited in all the previous trials put together. It was a pragmatic effectiveness trial that recruited patients from the majority of NHS cardiac surgery centres in the UK and therefore reflects current UK practice and is relevant to UK patients.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Research Magazine:Student Cardiovascular Magazine:Staff 2015-03-11T22:05:00Z Blog Entry English UG SS Guide 1.4 https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/english/existing-staff-and-students/english-ug-ss-guide-1.4 No publisher mn29 2015-03-11T16:50:00Z File Getting here https://www2.le.ac.uk/institution/kr3events/getting-here Please note that parking is limited on the University campus, so we recommend arriving by foot, bus or bike if possible.

Getting to the University from Leicester Railway Station

On Foot

Leicester Railway Station is within walking distance of the University (15 minutes). From the station entrance, turn left onto London Road, walk up the hill for about 400m, then turn right onto University Road and walk another 700m. The principal entrance to the Campus is Entrance 2, Mayor's Walk, on your left just before the Students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Union.

  • View this route on a map with directions

By Bus

You can catch a No. 80 bus, which is operated by Arriva and runs every 20 minutes. This takes less than five minutes to reach Mayor's Walk. The bus stop is located directly outside the station.

Getting to the University from St Margaret's Bus Station

By Bus

  • The no.48 bus, operated by Arriva, leaves St Margaret's every 15 minutes and takes about ten minutes to reach the University. (NB. The return journey is the no.47.)
  • The no.80 bus, also Arriva, leaves St Margaret's every 30 minutes and continues past the University to the Halls of Residence in Oadby. When returning, be aware that the 80A operates largely the same route but does not go to the railway station or city centre.

On Foot

If you're feeling fit and know your way through the city centre, the walk will take about 35-40 minutes.

  • View this route on a map with directions

Getting to the University by car

  • Map of nearby car parks (PDF)
]]> No publisher mjs76 2015-03-11T16:30:00Z Page Preparing for the New Science Curriculum KS4- Linear Assessment https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/education/cpd-for-teachers/our-cpd-sessions/session-information/preparing-for-the-new-science-curriculum-ks4-linear-assessment Support and guidance for teachers on teaching the new national curriculum in Science. This course will support science teachers in implementing the new National Curriculum. You will identify the key issues arising from the new Curriculum and consider how to audit and adapt existing schemes of learning to accommodate the changes.

]]> No publisher hr111 ECPD_Secondary 2015-06-19T08:30:00Z Event The Annual Science Subject Leader Day https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/education/cpd-for-teachers/our-cpd-sessions/session-information/the-annual-science-subject-leader-day Day course for Science subject leaders to meet, disscuss and share ideas. This \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnot to be missed\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd day for all established subject leaders will keep you updated with the latest from DfE, ofsted, ASE and many other science education organisations. Throughout the day there will also be opportunities to improve science subject knowledge and try a host of practical ideas and activities that can be used in science lessons. There will also be opportunity to share ideas, discuss concerns and network with other primary science subject leaders from the region. Participants will leave with a pack of materials to use back in school.

To book onto this session you\ufffd\ufffdcan fill out our online booking form, call us at 0116 252 3771 or email educationcpd@le.ac.uk.

Code: ECC13046
Audience: Primary
Trainer: Hester Binge/Debbie Eccles
Duration: 1 day
Cost: \ufffd\ufffd120*

All times and details of a session are given as a guide only. Education CPD+ reserves the right to amend these details where circumstances dictate.

]]> No publisher hr111 ECPD_Primary 2015-07-01T08:00:00Z Event Telford Campus Map https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/history/documents/TelfordCampusMap.pdf No publisher mb561 2015-03-11T15:56:17Z File Telford Welcome Letter https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/history/documents/TelfordWelcomeLetterUHG.docx No publisher mb561 2015-03-11T15:56:17Z File UHG Conference Booklet https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/history/documents/UHGbooklet2015.pdf No publisher mb561 2015-03-11T15:56:17Z File Thank you for your feedback! https://www2.le.ac.uk/library/about/news/thank-you-for-your-feedback Library Survey outcomes and actions Thank you to the 1,207 students and staff who completed our Library Survey. We are delighted that overall satisfaction with the Library continues to improve and that we performed well in all areas. We also performed well when benchmarked against the other University Libraries that undertook the survey.

You told us that your top priorities are:

  • Making electronic resources available from my home or office with information easily accessible for independent use
  • Providing quiet space for individual work with staff willing to help users

You said our strengths are:

  • Our staff who instil confidence in users and providing a Library that is comfortable and inviting

You said that you need more:

  • Electronic and print resources
  • Quiet spaces for individual work
  • Help with distinguishing between trustworthy and untrustworthy sources of information

\ufffd\ufffd

You can see the actions we will be taking and a summary of the LibQual+ survey findings here

Your feedback about this report and our actions are welcomed. Please email Jo Aitkins, Head of Public Services at jua1@le.ac.uk

]]> No publisher sc578 Library 2015-03-11T15:55:00Z News Item Hotly anticipated Varsity competition returns https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/march/hotly-anticipated-varsity-competition-returns Sporting contest between the University of Leicester and De Montfort University students begins The annual Varsity contest, in which University of Leicester students pit themselves against rivals De Montfort University in a range of different sports, officially begins today (11 March).

Sports such as netball, fencing, Tae Kwon-Do, climbing, lacrosse and many others will all be contested over a week that will determine the 2015 Varsity champion in Leicester.

Varsity culminates in the women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds and men\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds rugby matches taking place once again at the Leicester Tigers Welford Road stadium on Wednesday 18 March in front of what is always a large and noisy crowd. The women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds match kicks-off at 6.30pm followed by the men\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds match at 8.05pm. Tickets are \ufffd\ufffd5 in advance from the Students' Union.

The two teams have also been receiving some expert advice from two current Tigers players. England centre Anthony Allen and Terrence Hepetema have been coaching the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds and De Montfort University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds rugby teams respectively.

The women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds team are unbeaten for twelve years, and the men have won the competition two years in a row.

Both the men's and women's football teams will be battling it out at Aylestone Park on Monday 23 March, with the women's team kicking off at 5.15pm and men's team at 7.30pm. Tickets for\ufffd\ufffdboth matches are free and buses will be provided free of charge from outside the Students Union on campus and from John Foster Halls in Oadby, see the Students' Union website for times.

]]> No publisher pt91 Magazine:Staff Sports Magazine:Student 2015-03-11T15:45:00Z Blog Entry Certificate of Higher Education in Social Welfare, Advice and Guidance \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/lifelong-learning/parttime/course-pages/certificate-of-higher-education-in-social-welfare-advice-and-guidance-2020 Is this the course for me?\ufffd\ufffd

Modules

What skills will I gain?

Teaching and Assessment

Career relevance and employability

Opportunities for further study

Is this the course for me?

This qualification is for anyone working in, or aspiring to work in a broad range of advice work and social welfare roles. Admission priorities include local residents and those currently under-represented in social welfare, advice and guidance work. Most classes take place at the Highfields Centre in Leicester.

Modules

The course has six modules, taken over sixteen months:
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Information, Advice and Guidance
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Social Security Law
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Advice and Interviewing Skills
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Social Welfare Law 1 (Family Debt)
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd The English Legal System
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Social Welfare Law 2 (Immigration,
Housing and Employment)

What skills will I gain?

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Foundation knowledge of the English legal system and social security law
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd A broad understanding of contemporary issues in law as they relate to advice work
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd The ability to apply the taught elements of the course through a supervised placement in a professional advice/guidance organisation

Teaching and Assessment

You will be taught by experienced professional practitioners via formal lectures and seminars and will develop skills, knowledge and understanding through tutorials and small group work. Practical experience is gained via the placement/ voluntary work element. Assessment is through a combination of written assessments, exams, presentations, a placement diary and a report on an aspect of advice work.

Career relevance and employability

The course is designed to provide a thorough grounding and appropriate training for paid and voluntary advice and guidance workers and others interested or involved in providing advice and guidance on social welfare matters. Previous students have gone on to employment in a very diverse range of organisations including the Careers Service, Citizens Advice Bureau, Charities, Colleges, Local Authorities and Cultural and Community Centres. It is one of the few courses in the UK which caters specifically for the advice professional or volunteer.

Opportunities for further study

Successful completion of the course will give students 120 credits at HE level 1/FHEQ Level 4. As such, it provides an entry route into relevant courses at HE Level 2 /FHEQ Level 5 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd it may be possible for this Certificate course to be used to negotiate advanced standing on a range of full degree programmes both within the University of Leicester and beyond.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Subject to University approval

]]> No publisher va50 2015-03-11T15:40:19Z Page Postgraduate Certificate in Professional Studies (Supervision) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/lifelong-learning/counselling/pg/postgraduate-certificate-in-professional-studies-supervision-2020 Course Overview\ufffd\ufffd

What skills will I gain?

Entry Requirements

Teaching and Assessment

Course Times

Career relevance and employability

Opportunities for further study

Course Overview

The Postgraduate Certificate in Professional Studies (Supervision) provides a comprehensive training in supervision for experienced counsellors, psychologists and psychotherapists. The programme consists of three 20-Credit modules at Level M that are taught in six blocks of two days each. Participants are expected to engage in private study. All participants are required to take on at least one supervisee by the end of the first term.

What skills will I gain?

By the end of the three modules addressing supervision of counsellors and psychotherapists, students will be able to:

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Demonstrate an understanding of the roles and responsibilities of a supervisor.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Negotiate a working agreement with a potential supervisee.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Make decisions about complex ethical issues, based on firm understanding of the BACP Ethical Framework.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Discuss a range of models of supervision and be able to articulate the model they choose to use.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Critically evaluate the impact of organisations on the supervisory relationship.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Demonstrate competence in developing the supervisory relationship and in using appropriate supervisory skills.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Negotiate a working agreement with a supervision group, based on a broad understanding of group dynamics and the use of supervision groups.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Identify their own strengths and weaknesses as a supervisor and develop a strategy for continuing their professional development.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Recognise ways in which diversity influences the supervisory relationship and demonstrate appropriate insight, understanding and skills for working with a diverse client group.
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Integrate research evidence that impacts on the practice of supervision into their work.

Entry Requirements

Applicants for this programme should normally have a degree or equivalent, a qualification in counselling, psychotherapy or clinical psychology to at least Diploma level and be practicing counsellors, psychotherapists or applied psychologists with a minimum of three years\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd experience in that role. Ideally applicants will have BACP OR BABCP accreditation, UKCP registration or be eligible for registration, or have Chartered Clinical or Counselling Psychologist status. All students will need access to a computer and the internet.

Teaching and Assessment

The course will be taught by lecturers who are themselves psychotherapists and experienced clinical supervisors. The course is influenced by humanistic and psychodynamic concepts and is open to applicants who have been trained in any theoretical models, providing they are open to looking at the dynamics of the
supervisory process from a psychodynamic perspective. Each module is assessed by an assignment that is the equivalent of 5000 words. One assignment will be a tape recording of a supervision session accompanied by a transcription and critique.

Course Times

6 x 2-day blocks; Monday/Tuesday & Wednesday/Thursday. There are four teaching days each term:

Module 1
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Block 1: Monday 19 and Tuesday 20th October 2015
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Block 2: Wednesday 18 and Thursday 19th November

Module 2
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Block 1 Monday 11 and Tuesday 12 January 2016
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Block 2: Wednesday 2 and Thursday 3 March 2016

Module 3
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Block 1: Monday 23 and Tuesday 24 May 2016
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Block 2: Wednesday 8 and Thursday 9 June 2016

Times for each two-day block:
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Day One (Monday and Wednesday): 10.00 am \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 5.00 pm
\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Day Two (Tuesday and Thursday): 9.00 am \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 5.00 pm

Career relevance and employability

The programme will address a wide range of issues that are relevant to the practice of supervision, including ethics, contracts, models of supervision, working with groups, supervisory relationships, process, and organisational issues, as well as paying attention to issues of difference.

Opportunities for further study

It is intended that the award will provide the required training and developmental
experience that will lead candidates towards applying for Supervisor Accreditation with the BACP, and BPS Directory Specialism for Applied Psychology Practice Supervisors.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Subject to University approval
